meanings.def: two or more lines that are parallel to each other are the same distance apart at every point
examples: parallel lines
parallel to/with something The road and the canal are parallel to each other.
The lane is roughly parallel to the main road.
The road runs parallel with the coast.

meanings.def: very similar or taking place at the same time
examples: parallel trends
Though still a committed painter, in 1978 she launched a parallel career as a photographer.
Two poisonings have been reported recently in London and now there has been a parallel case in the Netherlands.

meanings.def: involving several computer operations at the same time
examples: parallel processing

meanings.def: two or more lines that run parallel to each other are the same distance apart at every point
examples: The road and the canal run parallel to each other.
The plane flew parallel to the coast.

meanings.def: in a way that is very similar or takes place at the same time
examples: The team's findings run parallel to those of other researchers.

meanings.def: a person, a situation, an event, etc. that is very similar to another, especially one in a different place or time
examples: These ideas have parallels in Freud's thought too.
This tradition has no parallel in our culture.
without parallel This is an achievement without parallel in modern times.
The move west suggests a parallel with the earlier American pioneer experience.
This weather pattern of the southern hemisphere has no parallel in the north.
We found a direct parallel in the attitudes of children in other countries.
There are interesting parallels between the 1960s and the late 1990s.
It is possible to draw a parallel between (= find similar features in) their experience and ours.
Parallels do exist between the author's family and that of Francie Coffin.
She saw an obvious parallel with her sister's predicament.
A close parallel to this behaviour is found in dolphins.

meanings.def: an imaginary line around the earth that is always the same distance from the equator; this line on a map
examples: the 49th parallel

meanings.def: with and at the same time as something/somebody else
examples: The new degree and the existing certificate courses would run in parallel.
Ann wanted to pursue her own career in parallel with her husband’s.

idioms.def: with and at the same time as something/somebody else
examples: The new degree and the existing certificate courses would run in parallel.
Ann wanted to pursue her own career in parallel with her husband’s.

meanings.def: to be similar to something; to happen at the same time as something
examples: Their legal system parallels our own.
The rise in unemployment is paralleled by an increase in petty crime.

meanings.def: to be as good as something
examples: a level of achievement that has never been paralleled
